member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.Internal.PipelineExecutor.DataSetState.IndexBlock
member.summary:
Index blocks track the subsets of data passed to each step. Initially, there is a single Root block that covers all the data. Calling creates a new child index block from the specified parent subset, and is tracked in the _indexMap collection.
After all child subsets have been completed ( called for all output), then will recursively remove all the child subsets from a parent (disabling public access to the data through ).

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.DataDecimation.MinimumLinearValuesPerPixel
member.summary: Gets the minimum density required by the default implementation before decimation will be performed on data.
member.remarks: If the density of data is below the threshold, the data will be returned unchanged.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.DataDecimation.MinimumLinearDataParallelization
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum amount of data required by the default implementation before decimation will parallelized operations.
member.value: The default value is 100,000.

remarks.para: If the amount of data is below the threshold, decimation will avoid the baseline parallelization overhead and process data values sequentially.
If the amount of data is above the threshold, decimation will process independent data values simultaneously across multiple threads.
To disable parallelization, set to .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Data.DataNormalization.None
member.summary: Gets a value that does not perform start value normalization.

The following example demonstrates setting the property to on a graph.
<ni:Graph GraphConfiguration.ConvertedDataNormalization="None" />
The following example demonstrates setting the property to on a scale.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble GraphConfiguration.ConvertedDataNormalization="None" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> </ni:Graph>

<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble GraphConfiguration.ConvertedDataNormalization="Zero" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> </ni:Graph>

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Internal.IHardwareRenderTargetInternal.IsHardwareAvailable
member.summary: Gets whether hardware rendering is currently available.

remarks.para: The availability of hardware rendering can change multiple times per application lifetime. For instance, a Remote Desktop session will disable WPF hardware acceleration for its duration, but hardware acceleration is restored if the session ends and the user logs back into the original machine.
Normally an instance will be used while hardware acceleration is unavailable.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.CursorBase
member.summary: Provides an abstract base class from which basic graph cursors are derived.
member.remarks:
This class provides basic functionality for all cursors.
Use the property to configure the way the cursor behaves when it is moved.
Cursors can display their position. Use the property to make the value label visible, and use the property to configure the appearance of the value label.
You can also specify an arbitrary to identify the cursor. Use the property to make the label visible, and use the property to configure the appearance of the label.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphBase
member.summary: Represents the base class for all graphs. This class provides the core functionality for managing and processing incoming data.
member.remarks:
Like the and properties on , provides the and properties to define the data displayed by the graph.
Each item in the collection corresponds to a plot displayed by the graph. Setting will automatically populate the collection, while using the collection directly allows for fine-grained management of the data passed to each plot.
The graph natively supports the following data and collection types:
Category Types
Numeric , , , , , , , , ,
Time , , ,
Composite , , , ,
Basic Collections 1D , 2D , ,
Waveform Collections , , ,
Charting Collections , ,
In addition to the built-in data types, graph data support can be extended through the use of .
When performing a memory-optimized read on an analog waveform in DAQmx 9.5 and earlier, only changes to the or of the analog waveform will cause the WPF graph controls to update. If your DAQmx task is not configured to use timing, call the method after the memory-optimized read to display the new waveform data in the WPF graph controls.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the syntax used to bind the property of the graph to an external source. In order for the graph to bind the in this way, the DataContext of the graph must be set to the object which defines the property being bound to. In this example the graph inherits the DataContext from that of its containing panel.
public class GraphModel { public ChartCollection<double> MyDataSource { get; set; } }
<ni:Grid x:Name="LayoutRoot" > <ni:Grid.DataContext > <ni:GraphModel /> </ni:Grid.DataContext >
<ni:Graph DataSource="{Binding MyDataSource}" /> </ni:Grid>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration
member.summary: Contains advanced configuration options for graph controls and control parts.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.MaintainGlobalLifetimeHardwareSession
member.summary: Gets whether to keep an active graphics hardware session open for the lifetime of the hosting application, when a graph uses hardware rendering.
member.value: The default value is .
member.remarks:
When repeatedly creating and removing a large number of graph controls, it can be more efficient to maintain a single graphics hardware session for the lifetime of the application.
When is set to , the first graph using hardware rendering will create a global hardware session that will remain active even after the graph original graph is removed from the UI.
When is set to , no global hardware session will be kept, and any existing session will be disposed. Each graph using hardware rendering will create a private hardware session, as necessary.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.DrawVisualCacheSizeProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: DrawVisualCacheSize
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets the size in kilobytes (KiB) of for the cache for method.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: The amount of memory the given graph should allocate to storing values for re-use. The default value is 256 KiB.

remarks.para: Re-rendering values takes a lot of effort from the CPU since each value is placed in TextBlock, laid out by WPF, rendered to a bitmap, then copied into the . This is all done on the UI thread, so responsiveness also slows for the entire WPF window. Caching reduces UI thread CPU usage by more than 500x.

At the standard WPF 12pt font, a 2-digit hexadecimal value takes about 0.85 KB. The default value therefore has enough space to store all possible 2-digit hexadecimal values. If an application has many of these graphs, then reducing this amount may be advisable to reduce memory usage.
Changing this value does not immediately update the existing cache; the cache is updated the next time the graph gets new data, or is called.
This does not apply to a of , which does not cache values. Also, cache is not pre-allocated; if DrawValue is never used, no cache will be allocated.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.IsAntiAliasedProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: IsAntiAliased
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether the graph uses anti-aliasing to render data.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: Indicates whether the graph uses anti-aliasing to render data. The default value is .
AttachedPropertyComments.remarks: Using anti-aliasing can reduce performance, particularly when using software rendering (such as over remote desktop).

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.AttemptRawDataRenderingProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: AttemptRawDataRendering
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether the graph should attempt to render plots with raw data.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: if the graph should attempt to render plots using raw data, or if the graph should always render plots using mapped relative data. The default value is .
AttachedPropertyComments.remarks: When set to , the graph will attempt to render plots using raw data. If the assigned to the plot does not support rendering that raw data, the graph will re-process the raw data to use standard relative rendering. Setting to will avoid this re-processing in the case where it is not supported.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.UseBackgroundRenderingProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: UseBackgroundRendering
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether to use background rendering (which improves performance by increasing data throughput and responsiveness).
AttachedPropertyComments.value: if the graph should use background rendering, or if the graph should render synchronously. The default value is .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.ProcessUpdatesWhenUnloadedProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: ProcessUpdatesWhenUnloaded
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether the graph should continue processing data updates after the graph has been unloaded.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: Indicates whether the graph should continue processing data updates after the graph has been unloaded. The default value is .
AttachedPropertyComments.remarks: Processing updates even after a graph is unloaded and not visible can be useful when there are other components depending on graph events, such as a in a different scope than the unloaded graph that is still visible.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.MinimumObservedDataProcessingGapProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: MinimumObservedDataProcessingGap
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets the minimum gap between processing observed data updates.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: The minimum gap between processing observed data updates, such as chart collections and waveform appends. represents no gap between updates. The default value is 10 milliseconds.

remarks.para: Observed data updates are processed at priority. When updates arrive faster than the graph can process them, the rest of the application can get starved (particularly rendering and user input), and the application can become unresponsive. Having a minimum gap guarantees that rendering, user input, and other lower-priority operations can be processed.

This value represents the minimum amount of time between the end of processing one set of observed data updates and beginning to process the next set. Thus, the gap always occurs, no matter how long each update takes to process. The gap is a minimum; other events queued on the and other work on the UI thread can make it take longer.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.UseBackgroundProcessingProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: UseBackgroundProcessing
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether the graph should process data asynchronously.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: Indicates whether the graph should process data asynchronously. The default value is .

remarks.para: When set to the default value of , the graph will attempt to move data processing operations on to a background worker thread, if the scales support asynchronous processing.
When set to , the graph will perform all data processing synchronously on the UI thread.

note.para: Graphs should be configured with set to when using a chart collection.

Avoid leaving set to when appending to a chart collection at a high rate. Since each append to a chart invalidates previous updates, the graph will resort to copying the full chart collection before processing any update on the background thread, reducing overall performance.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.ProcessAllAsynchronousUpdatesProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: ProcessAllAsynchronousUpdates
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether the graph should process all asynchronous data updates.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: Indicates whether the graph should process all asynchronous data updates (data assigned when is set to ). The default value is .

remarks.para: When either is set to or is set to , all data sent to the graph will be processed and rendered sequentially.

When is set to and is set to , the graph processses data asynchronously and displays the latest data available when rendering, discarding intermediate updates if more than one arrives during processing.

When both and are set to , data can backup on the background worker thread if the number of updates per second exceeds the number of updates the graph is able to process. The event can be used to track the approximate number of updates that are being processed. If the queue of unprocessed background updates causes issues, the graph can be configured to throttle updates by setting either or to .

note.para: Graphs should be configured with set to when using a chart collection.

Avoid setting to when using a chart collection. Since the graph processes incremental changes when a chart is updated, configuring the graph to discard updates may lead to rendering artifacts if a critical update is dropped.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.MinimumAsynchronousUpdateProcessingIntervalProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: MinimumAsynchronousUpdateProcessingInterval
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets the minimum interval at which asynchronous data updates are processed.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: The minimum interval at which asynchronous updates are processed. indicates updates will be processed continuously by the background worker thread. The default value is an interval of 30 frames per second (1000ms/30).

remarks.para:
When the graph is configured to use a background worker thread to process data by setting to ,
determines the minimum amount of time to wait before processing subsequent updates. At each interval, the background worker will drain the current set of items from the work queue before waiting for the next interval.

Used in combination with set to , a larger interval will increase the chance of consolidating subsequent redundant updates, reducing the overall amount of data processing performed by the graph, while maintaining a consistent UI update rate.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.MetadataAlwaysOverridesPlotLabelsProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: MetadataAlwaysOverridesPlotLabels
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets whether metadata overrides assigned plot labels.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: if plot names are replaced by metadata; otherwise, . The default value is .
AttachedPropertyComments.remarks: Metadata normally consists of device analog channel names or digital signal names. When this property is set to , those values override any pre-set names for a plot or signal.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.GraphConfiguration.ConvertedDataNormalizationProperty
member.summary: Identifies the attached property.
member.returns: The identifier for the attached property.

AttachedPropertyComments.name: ConvertedDataNormalization
AttachedPropertyComments.summary: Gets or sets the method used to normalize data when it is converted.
AttachedPropertyComments.value: The default value is , to let the graph choose the normalization method.

remarks.para: This attached configuration property can be applied to individual scales, or to the graph as a whole.

When data passed to the graph does not match the type of a scale, the data must be converted. During conversion to a floating-point type (such as for ), normalizing to values close to the high-precision range of the data type will help to preserve accuracy.

For example, a direct conversion of the date '2001-01-01 01:01:01 Z' to will result in a value of 63113886061, which leaves only ~5 additional decimal places of accuracy. If the conversion were normalized to start from a closer value, such as '2001-01-01 00:00:00 Z', then the result would be 3661, leaving ~12 decimal places of accuracy.

Note that while the implementation on the scale, and the
configuration will allow the scale labels to reflect the original data values, examining the scale programmatically will always return converted values.

Continuing the earlier example, although the scale label will use the original '2001-01-01 01:01:01 Z' value for formatting, the will use 63113886061 if normalization is disabled, or 3661 if the example normalized start value is used.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.IGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control.
member.remarks:
Like the and properties on , provides the and properties to define the data displayed by the graph.
Each item in the collection corresponds a plot displayed by the graph. Setting will automatically populate the collection, while using the collection directly allows for fine-grained management of the data passed to each plot.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.LayeredGraph.#ctor(NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.DataProcessorBase)

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.LayeredGraph.Children
member.summary: Gets the collection of child objects to display in the graph.
member.value: The collection of child objects to display in the graph.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to add graph-aware objects, like s and s, to the plot area of a graph.
<ni:Graph.Children> <ni:Cursor TargetBrush="Red" TargetShape="Diamond" CrosshairBrush="Blue" /> <ni:PointAnnotation Fill="Green" TargetShape="Diamond" ArrowBrush="Yellow" /> </ni:Graph.Children>

The following example demonstrates how to add arbitrary UI objects to the plot area of a graph.
<ni:Graph.Children> <!-- RelativePanel attached properties can be used to stretch a UI element across the entire plot area --> <ni:Image Source="map.png" RelativePanel.RelativeWidth="1.0" RelativePanel.RelativeHeight="1.0" /> </ni:Graph.Children>

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.RenderablePlot.Renderer
member.summary: Gets or sets the renderer used to draw the data associated with the plot.
member.value: The renderer used to draw the data associated with the plot. The default value is .
member.example:
This example shows how to configure the Renderer property.
<!-- Single renderer --> <ni:Plot> <ni:Plot.Renderer> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Blue" /> </ni:Plot.Renderer> </ni:Plot>
<!-- Multiple renderers. Note that the last renderer has the highest z-order. --> <ni:Plot> <ni:PlotRendererGroup> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Blue" /> <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Blue" /> </ni:PlotRendererGroup> </ni:Plot>

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.ThumbnailGraphAdapter.FilterAndCopyPlot(NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.IPlot)
member.summary: Copies of filters out each plot from the parent graph for the to use.
member.remarks: This can be overridden by inheritors to change how a plot is copied (usually setting up a copied plot differently or binding different properties to the parent plot), or to filter out specific plots. Plots are filtered out of the by returning .
member.param: The plot from the parent graph to copy.
member.returns: A copied plot, or .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.ThumbnailGraphAdapter.FilterAndCopyAxis(NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.IScale)
member.summary: Copies or filters out each axis from the parent graph for the to use.
member.remarks: This can be overridden by inheritors to change how a axis is copied (usually setting up a copied axis differently or binding different properties to the parent axis), or to filter out specific axes. Axes are filtered out of the by returning . Non-axis scales are always filtered out.
member.param: The scale from the parent graph to copy or filter out.
member.returns: A copied axis, or .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.ThumbnailGraphAdapter.FilterAndCopyChild(System.Object)
member.summary: Copies of filters out each child from the parent graph for the to use.
member.remarks: This can be overridden by inheritors to change how a child is copied (usually setting up a copied child differently or binding different properties to the parent child), or to filter out specific children. Children are filtered out of the by returning .
member.param: The child from the parent graph to copy.
member.returns: A copied child, or .

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Primitives.ThumbnailGraphAdapter.FilterData(System.Object)
member.summary: Passes through or filters out each data source from the parent graph for the to use.
member.remarks: Data is normally just passed through from the parent graph to the thumbnail. Inheritors can override this to filter out certain indices of data or to change the data sent to the thumbnail (for instance, sending pre-decimated data to the thumbnail while sending undecimated data to the graph). Data sources are filtered out of the by returning .
member.param: The data source from the parent.
member.returns: The original data source, or .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.BarPlotRenderer.DefaultInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the default interval to use for horizontal data.
member.value: The default interval to use for horizontal data, or to calculate a fallback value from the incoming sample count. The default value is .

remarks.para: The default interval is used when rendering bars for irregular and scatter data lacking a regular interval. This corresponds to the axis values. For example, when is 3, a value at 0 will cover the area from -1.5 to +1.5. If the the relative is 0.5, then the displayed bar width will be half the total width, from -0.75 to +0.75.
A value of is equivalent to a relative interval of the inverse of the number of samples. For example, if rendering with 20 values, each will have a relative interval of 0.05 (1/20).

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.ISupportValueInterpolation

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.LineStep
member.summary: Represents a strategy for displaying lines through a set of points.
member.remarks: Use the property on to determine how lines are displayed by the renderer.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.LineStep.None
member.summary: Gets a value that displays straight lines between points without any steps.
member.value: A object representing the specified display option.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to .
<ni:LinePlotRenderer LineStep="None" />

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.LineStep.DecimationAware
member.summary: Gets a value that displays straight lines between points without any steps.
member.value: A object representing the specified display option.
member.remarks: This interpolates identically to . However, for hardware or raster render mode, it adjusts the stroke thickness of the line if it detects that visual artifacts can result from dense data.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates setting the property to .
<ni:LinePlotRenderer LineStep="DecimationAware" />

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorBrushExtension
member.summary: Generates a from the specified brush and phosphor .
member.remarks: Use the phosphor brush extension in XAML on the brush properties of a to enabled the phosphor effect in a graph.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to use to apply a phosphor brush to line plot renderers in a graph.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Resources> <ni:FadeRamp x:Key="BlueRamp" Color="Blue" Duration="1000" DurationKind="Time" /> </ni:Graph.Resources>
<ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot Label="Fade from Green to Transparent"> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="{PhosphorBrush Green}" /> </ni:Plot> <ni:Plot Label="Render Black line, then fade to Blue"> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="{PhosphorBrush Black, {StaticResource BlueRamp}}" /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode
member.summary: Specifies phosphor modes for brushes.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.None
member.summary: Indicates the brush is always used, and will never be replaced by color data from the phosphor ramp.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Immediate
member.summary: Indicates the brush is ignored, and only the phosphor ramp is used for color data.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Deferred
member.summary: Indicates the brush is used for the first frame, and will be replaced by color data from the phosphor ramp on the next update.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PhosphorMode.Paused
member.summary: Indicates the first frame brush value is used to draw new data, leaving any existing phosphor values unchanged.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.PlotRenderer
member.summary: Represents an abstract base class for plot renderers.
member.remarks:
Plot renderers are used to display the data associated with a plot after it has been processed by a graph. You can use a plot renderer by assigning it to the property of a in a graph, or by adding it to the collection of default plot renderers on or .
Requirements are verified by the graph using reference equality.
When deriving from , create the data requirements once in the constructor for the renderer, and return the same instance for every call to .

member.summary: Gets information on the required data for the to render properly.
member.remarks:
The parent graph control will retrieve the once, and will re-query the requirements whenever new data is assigned, or a invalidation event occurs.
Requirements are verified by the graph using reference equality.
When deriving from , create the data requirements once in the constructor for the renderer, and return the same instance for every call to .

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedEventArgs
member.summary: Provides data for the event.
member.remarks:
If invalidation was caused by a change in appearance, use to notify all rendering systems to re-render.
If invalidation was caused by a change of position only (the appearance has not changed), use to notify only rendering systems that use position information to re-render.
If invalidate includes changes to both appearance and position, use .

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.VisualChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in appearance.
member.remarks: All rendering systems need to re-render.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.PositionalChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change of position only (the appearance has not changed).
member.remarks: Only rendering systems that use position information need to re-render.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.VisualAndPositionalChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in both appearance and position.

member.name: F:NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderInvalidatedReasons.LayerChange
member.summary: Indicates invalidation was caused by a change in layers.
member.remarks: Rendering systems that use the same in multiple layers (such as ) need to re-render, taking care to fully clear the renderer first to ensure visuals are not added to multiple layers due to sequential ordering of calls.

By default, Cartesian graphs are set to use an with a value of .
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring an axis on a graph. This example uses an in the XAML, which is equivalent to Axis<double>.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble Orientation="Horizontal" Range="0,30" Adjuster="None" Label="Time" Location="Near"> <ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> <ni:GridLines Stroke="Red" /> </ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> </ni:AxisDouble> <ni:AxisDouble Orientation="Vertical" Adjusted="FitExactly" Label="Voltage" Location="Far" InteractionMode="ReadOnly" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> </ni:Graph>

member.summary: Represents a collection of index and sample chart data values.
member.typeparam: The type of index data stored in the chart collection.
The type of sample data stored in the chart collection.

Use the class to chart numeric data in a graph.
The index values added to the chart collection must be strictly increasing, though the interval between individual values can be arbitrary. To have index values added automatically, use the class.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.ChartCollectionAnalogWaveform`1
member.summary: Represents a collection of chart data formed from sources.
member.typeparam: The type of the waveform data stored in the collection.
member.remarks:
Use the class to chart data in a graph.
The type of timing data passed to the graph is determined by the or properties on the appended waveforms. Each waveform must have the same timing type, and must start after the last timing value of the previous waveform.

member.summary: Appends the data in an to the collection.
member.param: The containing the data to add.
member.remarks:
After appending the new elements to the chart collection, this method raises the event.
The first time a waveform is appended to the collection, the type of timing information used by the waveform is stored (precision timing, normal timing, or none). All additional waveforms added must use the same kind of timing.
member.exception:
The timing of does not match the timing of the last waveform added.
-or-
The timing of starts at a value less than or equal to the end time of the last waveform added.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Cursor
member.summary: Represents a cursor that can display a single value in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the , , and properties to change the color, width, and length of the crosshair lines. The , , and properties determine the shape, color, and size of the value target.
Use and to associate the cursor with a particular data value in a plot. Use , , and to restrict the cursor to only a single plot or group of plots. The current value displayed by the cursor can be read from the property.

Use and to control the height of the displayed groups and signals. Use and to control the spacing between groups and signals.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.DigitalGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays digital data.
member.remarks: Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The and determine how the data is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.DigitalGraph.PlotAreaMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin around the plot area used to display scales.
member.value: The margin around the plot area used to display scales. The default value is a containing values.
member.remarks: When data is passed to the graph at a high rate, causing the scale ranges to change quickly, the repeated resizing of the plot area can degrade UI performance. Setting this property to a with fixed values (such as the value from after the graph has been displayed) will avoid these resize issues, preventing repeated re-drawing of the data.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.DigitalPlot.IsExpanded
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the plot is expanded.
member.value: if the plot should display expanded; otherwise, . The default value is .
member.remarks:
The data rendered by the plot is dependent on the value of both and , as described in the table below.
Display Mode Values Displayed
If is , then both the group and the signals are rendered; otherwise, only the group is rendered.
If is , then the signals are rendered; otherwise, the group is rendered.
Only the group is rendered.
Only the signals are rendered.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Graph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays data in a Cartesian coordinate system.
member.remarks:
Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. Scales associated with a plot determine how the data for that plot is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.
When performing a memory-optimized read on an analog waveform in NI-DAQmx 9.5 and earlier, only changes to the or of the analog waveform cause the WPF graph controls to update. If your NI-DAQmx task is not configured to use timing, call the method after the memory-optimized read to display the new waveform data in the WPF graph controls.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates how to configure the plots for a graph, including custom renderers for each plot, and explicit associations for which vertical scale to use.
Because only one horizontal scale exists, each plot will automatically use it for their horizontal dimension without the need for an explicit association. If two horizontal axes were declared, the plots would only use the first horizontal scale unless an explicit association was made (similarly for vertical axes).
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="xAxis" Orientation="Horizontal" /> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="yAxis1" Orientation="Vertical" /> <ni:AxisDouble x:Name="yAxis2" Orientation="Vertical" /> </ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot VerticalScale="{Binding ElementName=yAxis1}" > <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Green" StrokeThickness="2" StrokeDashArray="1 2" /> </ni:Plot> <ni:Plot VerticalScale="{Binding ElementName=yAxis2}" > <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Red" Shape="Ellipse" Size="5, 5" /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

The following example shows how to set up a graph to use a set of default renderers in the absence of either a plot itself for a particular trace of data, or a plot that has its Renderer set to .
Assuming the graph is given multi-plot data, the first trace of data would use the specified (a in this case). The second trace of data would start with the second renderer in the collection, and any further traces of data would cycle through the collection from there (the third trace would use the , the fourth would cycle to the , and so on).
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.DefaultPlotRenderers> <ni:BarPlotRenderer Fill="Blue" /> <ni:PointPlotRenderer Fill="Red" /> <ni:LinePlotRenderer Stroke="Green" /> </ni:Graph.DefaultPlotRenderers> <ni:Graph.Plots> <ni:Plot> <ni:LinePlotRenderer /> </ni:Plot> </ni:Graph.Plots> </ni:Graph>

member.remarks: When data is passed to the graph at a high rate, causing the scale ranges to change quickly, the repeated resizing of the plot area can degrade UI performance. Setting this property to a with fixed values (such as the value from after the graph has been displayed) will avoid these resize issues, preventing repeated re-drawing of the data.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.GraphInteraction
member.summary: Defines the basic interaction functionality for the types, such as .
member.remarks:
The table below describes each of the interactions provided by :
Interaction Description
No interaction. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be zoomed by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed horizontally by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed vertically by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be zoomed in around a point by clicking the mouse. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be zoomed out around a point by clicking the mouse. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be zoomed to fit the data assigned to the graph by clicking the mouse. Modifier Key: None
The plot area can be panned by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be panned horizontally by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
The plot area can be panned vertically by dragging the mouse. Modifier Key:
When an interaction is included in the collection, you can use the interaction by holding down the modifier key listed in the table above. The first interaction with that modifier key will be used.
When an interaction is set on the property, you can use the interaction without holding down any modifier key. The can be used to set the property at runtime.

member.summary: Occurs when the viewport horizontal range is about to change.
member.remarks: Programs monitoring this event can programmatically adjust the value or cancel the value change entirely. This can be useful for preventing the viewport from moving outside the range of data, or to allow the viewport to only have its minimum changed while charting. Since this is a relative range, the thumbnail view area covers a range of 0.0 to 1.0.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.Graticule
member.summary: Displays a grid-like view when added to the of a graph, independent of axes.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Controls.Graticule.DrawDivisionsAndTicks(NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.IRenderTarget,NationalInstruments.Controls.Rendering.RenderTargetOptions,System.Double,System.Windows.Controls.Orientation,System.Boolean,System.Double)
member.summary: Each "[Orientation]Segments" property represents the fractional number of blank segments used to divide the plot area. Divisions are drawn on the borders between each blank segment, including a fixed number of ticks between neighboring divisions. The "orientation" of the divisions is perpendicular to the segments (i.e. the horizontal segments are separated by vertical division lines). Divisions and ticks are drawn from the center of the plot area, outwards: The middle division is always centered in the plot area. The final divisions are always at our outside the plot area bounds, so never need to be drawn.
member.example:
Example showing 0 vertical segments, and 3 horizontal segments (1.5 on each side of the center):
| [ | | | ] |
Legend: [ | ] = plot area borders, and center division | | | = visible/drawn ticks and divisions | | | | | = all divisions = all ticks
member.param: The render target to draw to.
The render options to use.
The fractional number of segments.
The orientation of the lines.
to show divisions, or to only show ticks.
The length for tick marks, or if tick marks are not shown.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.GridLines
member.summary: Represents a set of grid lines in the plot area of a graph.
member.remarks: Use the , , and properties to change the color, width, and style of the grid lines.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates configuring grid lines on an axis in a graph.
<ni:Graph> <ni:Graph.Axes> <ni:AxisDouble Orientation="Vertical"> <ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> <ni:GridLines Stroke="Orange" StrokeDashArray="4,2" StrokeThickness="2" StrokeDashCap="Round" StrokeDashOffset="2" /> </ni:AxisDouble.MajorGridLines> </ni:AxisDouble> </ni:Graph.Axes> </ni:Graph>

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale
member.summary: Represents the third axis on an intensity plot, where colors are used to represent data values.
member.remarks:
A color scale can be used for the property on an , or for the property on an in a .
Use the collection to define the range of values displayed by the scale, and how each value is mapped to a color within the scale. Use the and properties to define the colors used for data that falls outside the range of .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale.Markers
member.summary: Gets the collection of color scale markers that determine how values are mapped to colors by the scale.
member.value: A collection of color scale markers that determine how values are mapped to colors by the scale. The smallest and largest values in the collection define the range of the scale.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale.LowColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color to display for values that fall below range defined by .
member.value: The color to display for values that fall below the scale range. The default color is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale.HighColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color to display for values that fall above range defined by .
member.value: The color to display for values that fall above the scale range. The default color is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale.IsInterpolated
member.summary: Gets or sets the interpolation behavior indicating how a value maps to a color if the value does not match an entry in the collection.
member.value:
A value that indicates how the color is calculated for values that do not match entries in the collection.
If , the color is calculated by taking a weighted mean of the colors associated with the color map entry values immediately above and below the value.
If , the color associated with the nearest lower color map entry value is used.
The default value is .

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.IColorScale.Adjuster
member.summary: Gets or sets the used to update the range defined by when data is received by the graph.
member.value: A used to update the scale. The default is .

member.summary: Gets or sets the method used to map values in the scale.
member.value: A object representing the method used to map values in the scale. The default is .

member.summary: Gets a color ramp representing the mapped color values in the scale.
member.value: A color ramp representing the mapped color values in the scale.

member.summary: Returns the color corresponding to the specified relative value.
member.param: A relative value.
member.returns: The color corresponding to the specified relative value on the color scale.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.IntensityGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays three-dimensional data in a two-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system, with color representing the third dimension.
member.remarks:
and determine how the data coordinates are scaled, and determines how the third dimension of data is mapped to color values.
By default, the intensity graph is configured to use an with a data type of to support a two-dimensional data source. For this kind of dense data source, each row and column index in the 2D array is used for the X and Y coordinates of the corresponding array value.
The intensity graph also supports collections of sparse data. Since there are no regular index values for sparse data, the size of the color rectangles is controlled by the and properties.
Although the intensity graph supports only a single plot, you can achieve more advanced combinations of intensity and other data by using an with the control.
member.example:
This example shows how to configure the color scale of an intensity graph in XAML.
<ni:IntensityGraph> <ni:IntensityGraph.ColorScale> <ni:ColorScale LowColor="Red" HighColor="Green"> <ni:ColorScale.Markers> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="0.0" Color="Yellow" /> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="0.5" Color="White" /> <ni:ColorScaleMarker Value="1.0" Color="Blue" /> </ni:ColorScale.Markers> </ni:ColorScale> </ni:IntensityGraph.ColorScale> </ni:IntensityGraph>

member.summary: Represents a legend control used to display symbols and descriptions of another object, such as the plots or cursors of a graph.
member.remarks:
A legend control displays symbols and labels for a specific set of elements provided through the property, such as the plots or cursors of a graph.
To bind a specific set of elements, such as all the plots on a , bind to the collection. To display every element in a graph, bind to the graph itself. contains the collection of all objects that are displayed in the legend.
The size and background of each symbol in the legend control are determined by the and properties. To match how an object is displayed in the plot area of a graph, bind to the of the graph.

member.summary: Acts as a filter for which objects are displayed in the legend.
member.param: An item to filter.
member.returns: if should be displayed in the legend; otherwise, .
member.remarks: The default implementation filters out instances, which cannot appear in the visual tree more than once. This method is used to set the property.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.MixedGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays analog and digital data.
member.remarks: Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The scales determine how the data is scaled. The displayed data can be navigated through pan and zoom methods, both programmatically and interactively. Additional methods allow finding visual parts of the graph through hit testing, and mapping between screen and relative coordinates.

member.summary: Gets the calculated margin around the plot area used to display scales.

member.name: P:NationalInstruments.Controls.MixedGraph.PlotAreaMargin
member.summary: Gets or sets the margin around the plot area used to display scales.
member.value: The margin around the plot area used to display scales. The default value is a containing values.
member.remarks: When data is passed to the graph at a high rate, causing the scale ranges to change quickly, the repeated resizing of the plot area can degrade UI performance. Setting this property to a with fixed values (such as the value from after the graph has been displayed) will avoid these resize issues, preventing repeated re-drawing of the data.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.MultiPlotCursor
member.summary: Represents a cursor that is associated with values from multiple plots using an axis in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the and properties to change the color and width of the crosshair line. The , , and properties determine the shape, color, and size of the value targets.
Use the property to orient the cursor and display values from all plots that use the axis. Use the property to position the cursor along the axis. The current values displayed by the cursor can be read from the collection.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.PointAnnotation
member.summary: Represents an annotation that highlights a data point in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use and to position the annotation on a specific data point along the and in the graph.
Use the , , , and properties to change the shape, size, and color of the annotation visual.
Use the property to position the in relation to the annotation visual, and use the , , , and properties to change the color, shape, and size of the arrow drawn from the to the annotation visual.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.PolarGraph
member.summary: Represents a graph control that displays data in a Polar coordinate system.
member.remarks:
Plots control how data in the graph is rendered. The and determine how the data is scaled.
When given or data, the polar graph will automatically use the and values from the data. When given data, the polar graph assumes that the and values from the data are in the appropriate domain for the and , respectively.
By default, the polar graph is configured to display data in degrees. To display data in radians, set the property to a with a of .

Use and to position the annotation across a specific range along the and in the graph.

member.name: T:NationalInstruments.Controls.RangeCursor
member.summary: Represents a cursor that is associated with a range of values along axes in a graph.
member.remarks:
In addition to the basic members provided by , you can configure the appearance of the in several different ways.
Use the , , and properties to change the outline and color of the range area.
Use the , , , and properties to control the initial position of the cursor. If only one range is set, the cursor will draw to infinity for the other range. The current range displayed by the cursor can be read from the and properties.

member.summary: Represents a graph that allows data to be drawn interactively in the graph.
member.remarks:
extends with support for interactive drawing of data through the class and property.
The collection controls how interactively drawn data is rendered. When manually adding a to , it is recommended that the and properties be set to , so that only is used to automatically adjust scales.
